text:
Yenimata and KO KINAL for the Hypothetical
The Trojan Horse is used by the government as a "Trojan Horse" in order to divest the most lucrative and strategically important public enterprises, complains KINAL with a timely inquiry submitted to Parliament.



Olga Panagiotidou, CNN Greece 12:59, 05 November 2019
Led by Fofi Gennimata, KINAL accuses the government of not only hitherto dealing with the substantial problems posed by SYRIZA's policy of mortgaging public property, the only change it has hitherto considered necessary for the institution to function. of EESYP SA is the increase in the salaries of "our own children".
KINAL invites the Minister of Finance to answer the following questions:

Why is the government not renegotiating the terms of utilizing Public Property to overturn Mr Tsipras's 99-year commitment, despite pre-election criticizing SYRIZA for his choice?
Why has it not, at least as a first step, changed the way in which the Board of Supervisors of ESSYP is appointed, in line with the law proposal we have tabled and which never came to Parliament for debate by the previous parliamentary majority?
Because to date it has not abolished the decision of Mr. Tsakalotos and has not canceled the Government Gazette 2317B΄ / 19.6.2018 and Government Gazette 2320B΄ / 19.6.2018, in order to return the rest (approximately 7,000) of the 10119 properties. which have been transferred to the ESYSYP, and has not also made public the list concealed by the SYRIZA government refusing to answer the persistent questions of our Members and MPs of ND?
Why, instead of following a meritocratic and transparent process of appointing Public Enterprises, with a public notice and strict criteria - evaluation procedures, continues the practice of appointing "our own children"?
Why does the government, instead of planning the exploitation of retained and unused public property, proceed through the Treasury to divest the most lucrative and strategic Public Enterprises, undermining their future contribution to the exploitation of its natural resources and comparative advantage?
Why is the Government not using parliamentary processes in a substantive discussion of the proposals put forward by the Movement for Change, with the aim of developing a unified national strategy on how resources for development will be secured through development of public property, in particular for public investment, social infrastructure and the creation of new jobs, as well as the strengthening of the insurance system through the Gender Fund;
